intro: Cassytha aphylla, commonly known as the hairless dodder, is a parasitic flowering plant native to tropical and subtropical regions. It lacks true leaves and stems, relying entirely on its host for nutrients. The plant produces small, inconspicuous flowers that are typically white or greenish in color. Its reproductive strategy involves producing copious amounts of seeds, which can remain viable for extended periods. Botanically, it is classified within the family Convolvulaceae, sharing characteristics with other members of the morning glory family.
